Description.val:
The FY 2021 funding request was reduced by $0.765 million to account for the availability of prior year execution balances.

This budget line item funds the procurement for Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG) life cycle support modifications and upgrades required aboard Ford Class Carriers, Jet Car Track Site (JCTS) and Runway Arrested Landing Site (RALS) systems.  Modifications included in the budget support fatigue life, obsolescence and performance enhancements to ensure the system remains operational throughout the life of the program. AAG will replace Mark 7 arresting gear aboard Ford Class aircraft carriers and will provide the U.S. Navy with the ability to recover existing and projected aircraft carrier based tail-hook equipped air vehicles well into the 21st century.  AAG will enhance operational capability, provide increased operational availability, while reducing manning, maintenance and support costs.  AAG is installed aboard CVN-78 as well as two land based test sites JCTS and RALS. 

FY 2017 ($2.2M) and Prior Years ($74.7M) funded under Aircraft Support Equipment (BLI 4213 and BLI 4216).

Justification.val:
The increase from FY 2020 to FY 2021 is due to the funding required for Mod II Water Twister (WT) procurements for CVN-79 and installation and completion of the material required for CVN-78.  CVN-78's Mod II Water Twisters will be installed during the Planned Incremental Availability (PIA2) in FY24, and CVN-79 Mod II Water Twisters will be installed during Post-Shakedown Availability (PSA) beginning in 3Q FY23.  CVN-79 is being constructed with Mod I WT onboard.  The program will be using OPN to remove and modify the previously installed Mod I WTs on CVN-79 making them full up Mod II WTs.  OPN is only funding the WT Mod II procurement/parts and the installation portion of WT Mod II.

The change in budget exhibit strategy in FY 2020 and out is to provide funding in Block upgrades to allow the program to address the most critical ECPs for the two land based units, Runway Arrested Landing Site (RALS), Jet Car Track Site (JCTS) and onboard CVN-78.  With swift changes in software updates and associated subsystems, impending cybersecurity mandates and changes driven by continuing correction of deficiencies out of RDT&E, the limited funding profile creates a dynamic situation in effectively executing this OPN Line Item to support an ever-changing list of unanticipated priority updates.

The logic of Block upgrades will provide the program more flexibility to address competing priorities of what become the most critical obsolescence, reliability, operational or safety upgrades in a given year.  It also avoids multiple overlapping software releases and design rework.  The block upgrades are categorized as follows: Obsolescence, Reliability Improvement upgrades, Operational Capability Improvements and Safety of Flight/Operations as well as the associated non-recurring engineering (NRE).  Each Block will generally be staggered by two (2) years to provide sufficient time for the design of each block and to level load Engineering Resources.  Each block will conduct performance validation testing in the 3rd year, with kit manufacture in the 4th year and install in the 5th year.  These lead times will also allow each Block to be available and leverage ship construction and availability schedules. 

Notes for Installation Schedule:
1.  Installations are subject to change with ship availability schedule updates.
2.  The year-to-year unit installations costs will vary and can exceed the projected yearly inflation rate due to the hardware installation cost being dependent on quantity and location of the ship at the time of install or which site is being update, which CVN, and the ships baseline configuration.
3.  Production lead time includes pre-installation checkout, kitting with other installation hardware and drawings, and time to deliver the hardware to the installation site.

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 4.1 Integrated Logistics Support - The increase from FY20 to FY21 is to support the logistic products that need updated to support Mod II Water Twisters.

Cost Element 4.2 Production Engineering - The increase from FY20 to FY21 is to provide the additional engineering support associated with Water Twister Mod II and the various engineering efforts related to the Block I upgrades for AAG.

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 1.1.1 Water Twister - The funding in FY19 provided the rough machining for six (6) rotor shafts for CVN-78 provided at a reduced cost as a result of the concurrency clause in the CVN-78 contract.   It also provided for the long lead items and materials provided by Lakehurst Prototype Manufacturing Department (PMD) for forgings (non-rotor) and inboard cover materials to expedite the CVN-78 upgrade to WT MOD II to be able to install them during PIA2 in FY24.  Due to the lead times of the materials for the rough machining of the rotor shafts the procurement was required in FY19 to meet the installation availability of CVN-78 and to take advantage of the economic order quantity pricing of the four (4) procured in FY18.  Due to the time required to do the rough machining it was necessary to start in FY19 to meet CVN-78's maintenance availability.
The 4 units being installed in FY20 are for the two land based test sites.  Runway Arrested Landing Site (RALS) and Jet Car Track Site (JCTS) both in Lakehurst, NJ.

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT Install:: Installation Name: 1.1.1) Water Twister

Name.@footnote: 1.1.2 Water Twister Mod II:  The funding provides for a total quantity of twelve (12) Mod II WTs.  (6 for CVN-78 and 6 for CVN-79).  Variations in unit cost is due to the availability of long lead parts and learning curve efficiencies from 25 months to 17 months. As a result Mod II WT lead times decrease in FY21 through FY24. The six (6) procurements in FY21 benefit from long lead hardware provided from FY19 funding, but these are the first to be assembled in Production and are also dependent on Detail machining being released.  The six (6) units in FY21 also benefit in cost savings from the Rough Machining provided in FY19 under consideration from the concurrency clause under the CVN-78 contract. To limit administrative lead times, efforts are worked in parallel to provide the most efficient delivery of Mod II WTs for CVN-78 and CVN-79.

ImplementationMethodName.val: HII (Huntington Ingallls Industries):: Installation Name: Water Twister Mod II

Name.@footnote: Cost Element 1.2.1 Non-Recurring Engineering - Provides the associated non recurring engineering associated with the Mod II Water Twister updates in FY21.

Cost Element 2.1.1 - Block I Upgrade includes four (4) major categories of Block Upgrades:  1.  Obsolescence: provides funding for ECPs used to address critical or obsolete parts in any of the major or subcomponent systems within AAG. 2.  Reliability Improvements/Upgrades: provides funding for ECPs to address any issues that support reliability of AAG's system at RALS, JCTS and onboard CVN 78.  3.  Operational Capability Improvements: provides funding for ECPs that specifically address operational capability improvements which are mostly driven by changes as a result of findings during Correction of Deficiency testing.  4.  Safety of Operations/Flight: provides funding for ECPs that directly affect safety of flight operations that might limit flight operations during normal optempo.  Additionally ECPs for items such as software upgrades to components or sub system components that cause issues under normal operating conditions of AAG will be included in each of the four categories when software updates are required within the Block of upgrades.  Funding within the block will also be used to support directed cyber mandates to ensure compliance of cyber issues in AAG's operating system.  The current Block I plans to address Halfbridge Reliability and Obsolescence (48 / shipset), Purchase Cable Drum (PCD) Follower Screw Failure / Reliability (6 / shipset), SV3 Valve Safety Failure modes (6/shipset); Supernut Reliability (6/Shipsets); PCD Pin Retention Safety (6 / Shipsets), Integrated Software and Cyber Testing and patches).

ImplementationMethodName.val: AIT:: Installation Name: AAG Block I Upgrade

Name.@footnote: 2.2.1 Non-Recurring Engineering - provides the associated non-recurring engineering with the various Block I upgrades that support Obsolescence, Reliability Improvements/Upgrades, Operational Capability Improvements and Safety of Operations/Flight.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: AAG Block II Upgrade

Description.val:
This budget line item funds the procurement for Advanced Arresting Gear (AAG) life cycle support modifications and upgrades required aboard Ford Class Carriers, Jet Car Track Site (JCTS) and Runway Arrested Landing Site (RALS) systems.  Modifications included in the budget support fatigue life, obsolescence and performance enhancements to ensure the system remains operational throughout the life of the program. AAG will replace Mark 7 arresting gear aboard Ford Class aircraft carriers and will provide the U.S. Navy with the ability to recover existing and projected aircraft carrier based tail-hook equipped air vehicles well into the 21st century.  AAG will enhance operational capability, provide increased operational availability, while reducing manning, maintenance and support costs.  AAG is installed aboard CVN-78 and in two land based test sites at JCTS and RALS. 

CVN-78 was delivered with several known deficiencies for AAG.  FY 2021 funding provides Mod II Water Twister procurements for CVN-79 and installation and completion of the material required for CVN-78.  FY 2021 also continues to provide funding for life cycle improvement Block I upgrades for the procurement and installation at RALS, JCTS and onboard CVN-78. The supporting non-recurring engineering (NRE) is required to continue to address and field critical software updates, maintain cyber security compliance and hardware obsolescence ECPs onboard CVN-78 and at RALS and JCTS.  

CVN-78 has a Planned Incremental Availability (PIA) in FY 2021 when a significant amount of obsolescence issues will be addressed for CVN-78 as well as the required updates at RALS and JCTS to maintain configuration across all three sites.  The degree of complexity and nature of the ECPs are varying in cost as well as in quantities onboard CVN-78 for RALS and JCTS depending on the conditions at each of the three sites.

FY 2017 and prior funded under Aircraft Support Equipment (BLI 4213 and BLI 4216).
